title: 109_hr3492
content: The Consumer Credit Card Protection Act of 2005 prohibits universal defaults on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits creditors from using adverse information to increase interest rates on credit card accounts. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits credit card issuers from using adverse information to raise the interest rate on a consumer's account, unless the consumer's actions are directly related to the account. The issuer must clearly inform the consumer about this limitation in any required disclosures or statements. SEC. 3. BOX DISCLOSURE OF PAYMENT PERIOD FOR MINIMUM PAYMENTS ON CREDIT CARD BALANCE. Section 127(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new requirements for minimum payment terms on credit card balances. This includes clear and conspicuous repayment information in a tabular format, showing the required minimum monthly payment as a dollar figure and a percentage of the outstanding balance. The Truth in Lending Act now requires credit card statements to include clear repayment information, including the number of months it would take to pay off the balance by making only minimum payments. The Truth in Lending Act mandates credit card statements to provide clear repayment details, including the time needed to pay off the balance with minimum payments. Creditors must apply the relevant annual percentage rate for disclosures, considering different rates for various outstanding balances. The Truth in Lending Act requires credit card statements to disclose repayment details, including the time to pay off the balance with minimum payments. Creditors must apply the appropriate annual percentage rate to outstanding balances, regardless of fixed or variable rates. If an introductory rate is in effect, the creditor must consider future rate adjustments based on an index or formula. The Truth in Lending Act mandates disclosure of annual percentage rates for introductory or temporary periods, based on fixed or variable rates and future adjustments tied to an index or formula. The Truth in Lending Act requires disclosure of annual percentage rates for introductory or temporary periods, based on fixed or variable rates and future adjustments tied to an index or formula. The rate referred to in subclause (I) would be effective as of the disclosure date for the remainder of the amortization period. SEC. 4. Advanced notice required before increasing rates or fees on credit card accounts. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan. The Truth in Lending Act now requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates or fees on credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan, with specific timelines for when the increase may take effect. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of interest rate or fee increases on credit card accounts under open end consumer credit plans, with specific timelines for implementation. The Truth in Lending Act requires advance notice of fee increases on credit card accounts, with a 30-day period for the obligor to receive notification before any fees can be imposed. The Truth in Lending Act mandates advance notice of fee increases on credit card accounts, with a 30-day period for the obligor to receive notification before any fees can be imposed. The notice must explain how, when, and why a fee will be imposed, as well as the options available to address it.
